name: Re-categorize docs into base, element, forms, ui-components, blocks
description:
Beads description:
Reorganize documentation categories to match the component taxonomy.

FINAL CATEGORIES:

1) BASE - tokens + default element styles (no classes, just foundation)
   - CSS custom property tokens (spacing, colors, shadows, borders, line-heights, easing)
   - Default HTML element styles (h1-h6 elements, body, links, img, etc.)

2) LAYOUT - structural patterns
   - .layout-card, .layout-sidebar, .layout-split, .layout-three-col
   - .layout-readable, .layout-holy-grail, .full-bleed
   - .stack, .cluster, .carousel, .reel, .flex, .grid, .split, .readable

3) ELEMENT - standalone building blocks
   - .box (+ .box-ghost, .box-glow, .box-semi-gloss)
   - button/.button (+ .mini, .primary, .error, .warning, .success, .ghost)
   - table/.table
   - .callout (+ .warning, .error, .ghost, .success, .hard)
   - .circle

4) FORMS - form inputs and validation
   - input, select, textarea base styles
   - label
   - Validation states (.error, .success, .warning)

5) UI-COMPONENTS - composed components
   - .swipe (+ .stop, .full-bleed)

6) BLOCKS - full patterns
   - .header (+ .border, .sticky)

7) UTILITIES - modifier/helper classes
   - .auto-color (+ .chroma)
   - .fc (fluid container)
   - .h1-.h6 (heading styles on non-headings)
   - .fs-* (font size utilities)
   - .visually-hidden, .no-list, .row, .aspect-*

name: Add CodeExample Svelte component for docs
description:
Beads description:
Create a reusable Svelte 5 component for documentation code examples using svelte-highlight (https://github.com/metonym/svelte-highlight).

Similar to https://base-ui.com/react/components/accordion but simpler - since Graffiti is CSS-only, no props table or API reference needed. Just:
1. Live preview in a resizable container
2. Syntax-highlighted source code

Requirements:
- Accept a demo component as a prop
- Import the demo as both:
  1. A rendered component (to display in a resizable preview box)
  2. A raw string (for syntax highlighting with svelte-highlight)
- Resizable preview container so users can test responsive behavior
- Syntax highlighted code block showing the source
- Should work with Graffiti's light/dark theming
- Svelte 5 patterns only (runes, snippets, etc.)
- Clean, minimal UI - let the examples speak for themselves

Reference: https://github.com/metonym/svelte-highlight

name: Add chip/pill component for selectable tags
description:
Beads description:
## Summary
Add a chip/pill component for displaying selectable tags, categories, or filter options. Similar to Material Design chips or filter pills.

## Requirements
- Pill/rounded shape styling
- Support for icon + text (icon optional)
- Selected vs unselected states (selected = filled/primary color, unselected = ghost/outline)
- Works well inside `.cluster` layout for horizontal wrapping groups
- Light and dark theme support

## Visual Reference
Rounded rectangular elements with:
- Icons on the left (optional)
- Text label
- Clear selected state (blue fill + border) vs unselected (gray outline)

## Implementation Notes
- Use `.chip` as the base class
- Consider `.chip.selected` or using `aria-pressed="true"` for selected state
- Demo should use icons from https://phosphoricons.com/
- Demo should show a category/skill selector similar to the reference image (Technology categories like Front-End Development, Back-End Development, etc.)

- CSS anchor names are global, so positioning breaks with multiple dropdowns

Solution:
- Use a CSS variable like --anchor-name that users set per-dropdown
- Update demos to show unique anchor names for each dropdown
- e.g. style="--anchor-name: --my-dropdown"

name: Fix viewport-based layout issues
description:
Beads description:
Several Graffiti components use viewport-based units (vw, vh) which cause issues when nested inside constrained containers like sidebar layouts.

**Problematic components:**
- .header - uses viewport-based sizing
- .full-bleed - breaks out to viewport width
- .swipe.full-bleed - same issue

**The problem:**
When these components are used inside a sidebar layout or any constrained container, they overflow or push the container because they reference the viewport, not their container.

**Potential solutions to explore:**
1. Container queries - make layouts auto-set container-type on main content areas
2. Documentation changes - show these components in appropriate contexts, warn about viewport limitations
3. Modifiers - add .contained variants that use container-relative units
4. Rethink the components - maybe full-bleed shouldn't use vw at all

**Related:**
- Fluid typography system also uses vw but has .fc class for container-based sizing
- May need to audit all vw/vh usage in drop-in.css

This epic should result in either:
- Fixed components that work in nested contexts
- Clear documentation about when/where to use these components
- Or both
